case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. The Bank

facts.text: Appeal is Civil Appeal No. 675 of 1965 from Mysore High Court judgment dated December 11, 1961 in I.T.R.C. No. 13 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JuRISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 675 of 1965. Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 11, 1961 of the Mysore High Court in I.T.R.C. No. 13 of 1959.

facts.text: The respondent Bank is a public limited company carrying on banking business at head office in Mangalore and branches.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent  hereinafter referred to as the Bank  is a public limited companypany carrying on business of banking at it s head office in Mangalore and its branches in various places.

facts.text: Bank opened one branch in Karachi on November 15, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: It opened one branch in Karachi on November 15, 1946.

facts.text: Partition of India in 1947.

anchor.surface_text: After the partition of India in 1947, the currencies of the two dominions of India and Pakistan companytinued to be at par

facts.text: Devaluation of Indian Rupee on September 18, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: until there was a devaluation of the Indian Rupee on September 18, 1949. As Pakistan did number devalue her rupee,

facts.text: Exchange ratio agreed on February 27, 1951: 100 Pakistani Rupees = 144 Indian Rupees.

anchor.surface_text: The exchange ratio between the two companyntries was number determined until February 27, 1951. On this date it was agreed that a hundred Pakistani Rupees were equivalent to a hundred and forty four Indian rupees.

facts.text: On devaluation date, Karachi Branch had Rs. 3,97,221/- belonging to head office.

anchor.surface_text: On the date of devaluation of the Indian Rupee the Karachi Branch of the Bank had with it a sum of Rs. 3,97,221/belonging to its head office.

facts.text: Impossible to remit amount to head office for long time due to currency difficulties.

anchor.surface_text: Owing to the difficulties of the currency situation it was impossible to remit the amount to the head office for quite a long time.

facts.text: State Bank of Pakistan permitted remittance on July 1, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On July 1, 1953, the State Bank of Pakistan permitted its remittance to India.

facts.text: Remitted amount equivalent to Rs. 5,71,038/- in Indian currency.

anchor.surface_text: In terms of Indian currency the said amount became equivalent to Rs. 5,71,038/-. Thus there was an appreciation of the value

facts.text: Profit of Rs. 1,73,817/- due to appreciation.

anchor.surface_text: of the amount remitted from the Karachi branch and the Bank made a profit of Rs. 1,73,817/-. After making certain deductions,

facts.text: After deductions, Rs. 1,70,746/- transferred to Contingencies Reserve Account.

anchor.surface_text: After making certain deductions, the head office of the Bank transferred a sum of Rs. 1,70,746/- to its Contingencies Reserve Account.

facts.text: In return for assessment year 1954-55, Bank claimed Rs. 1,70,746/- as capital gain not taxable.

anchor.surface_text: In its return for the assessment year 1954-55, the Bank claimed that this sum was a capital gain and was number taxable.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected claim by order dated February 9, 1955, holding it revenue receipt.

anchor.surface_text: By his order dated February 9, 1955 the Income-tax Officer rejected the claim holding that the said amount of Rs. 1,70,746/- was a revenue receipt.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner affirmed ITO order.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Income- tax Officer was affirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner in appeal.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal rejected Bank's appeal by order dated November 23, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Bank took the matter in further appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal which rejected the appeal by its order dated November 23, 1956.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question of law to High Court at instance of Bank.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Bank the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal referred the following question of law for the determination of the High Court

facts.text: Question: Whether exchange difference of Rs. 1,70,746/- assessable under Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the aforesaid exchange difference of Rs. 1,70,746/- is assessable under any of the provisions of the Indian Income-tax Act?

facts.text: Mysore High Court by order dated December 11, 1961 held exchange difference not assessable.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated December 11, 1961 the High Court reversed the finding of the Appellate Tribunal and held that the exchange difference

facts.text: Remittance actually took place on July 3, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The State Bank of Pakistan granted the permission on July 1, 1953 and the remittance actually took place two days later i.e., on July 3, 1953.

facts.text: Tribunal found until April 3, 1951 Bank carried no foreign exchange business.

anchor.surface_text: It has been found by the Appellate Tribunal that until April 3, 1951 when the Bank was permitted to carry on business in Pakistan currency it carried on numberforeign exchange business.

facts.text: Bank obtained general licence for foreign currencies on April 25, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Even after such permission was granted and even after the Bank obtained on April 25, 1953 a general licence to carry on business in all foreign currencies

facts.text: Money lying idle in Karachi branch, not utilised in banking operations.

anchor.surface_text: the appellate Tribunal has found that the money was lying idle in the Karachi branch and it was number utilised in any banking operation

facts.text: Amount Rs. 3,97,221/- was blocked and sterilised from devaluation to remittance.

anchor.surface_text: According to the agreed statement of the case the amount of Rs. 3,97,221/- was blocked and sterilised for the period from the devaluation of the Indian rupee upto the time of its remittance to India.

facts.text: Original and supplementary statements of case dated May 15, 1957 and August 14, 1959 were agreed.

anchor.surface_text: It is a matter of significance that the original statement of the case dated May 15, 1957 and Supplementary statement of the case dated August 14, 1959 were, both agreed statements.

facts.text: Appellant conceded before High Court no evidence that blocked balance used for operations.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, it appears that it was companyceded by the appellant before the High Court that there was numberevidence that the blocked balance was, in fact, employed by the Karachi branch

facts.text: During April 3, 1951 to April 25, 1953 dealings in new account, old balance not utilised.

anchor.surface_text: In the supplementary statement of the case the appellate Tribunal stated that during the period April 3, 1951 to April 25, 1953 there were dealings between India and Pakistan Offices of the Bank,

facts.text: Supreme Court holds increment is capital receipt, not assessable.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the money changed -its character of stock-in-trade when it was blocked and sterilised and the increment in its value owing to the exchange fluctuation must be treated as a capital receipt.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JuRISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 675 of 1965. Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 11, 1961 of the Mysore High Court in I.T.R.C. No. 13 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The question involved in this appeal is whether the profit of the Bank on account of fluctuation of exchange arose in the course of trading operation of the Bank or whether it was incidental to any such trading operation. If by virtue of exchange operations profits are made during the course of business and in connection with business transactions, the excess receipts on account of conversion of one currency into another would be revenue receipts.

concepts.interpretation: Profit is revenue if from exchange operations in course of or incidental to business; capital if not.

anchor.surface_text: Imperial Tobacco Company Kelly 1 . In that case, a tobacco manufacturing companypany in England with a view to buying tobacco leaf in the U.S.A. during the leaf season, used to provide itself with dollar currency in advance by purchasing the same beforehand. On the outbreak of war, owing to Governmental restrictions the companypany had to suspend its buying operations in U.S.A. Later, the British Treasury requisitioned the accumulated dollars and paid the companypany sterling in exchange.  1  25 T.C. 292.

precedents.cited_proposition: excess receipts due to appreciation in value of foreign currency held for business purposes retain revenue character and are taxable even if later requisitioned by government
precedents.cited_holding: the excess receipts were profits assessable to income-tax and the acquisition of the dollars was the first step in the commercial transaction of the company. The dollar was a commodity of the company and it became a surplus stock to the companys requirements on the restriction on purchase and original revenue character would number be altered by the circumstance of the Governmental controls requisitioning the dollars

anchor.surface_text: Landes Brothers Simpson 1  where a similar view was taken. On the contrary, Counsel for the respondent relied upon the decision in McKinlay  H. M. Inspector of Taxes  v. H. T. Jenkins Son 2  Ltd. in which it was held that the profit by exchange operations would be capital profit if the profit did number companye in by way of business but by means of an investment in foreign currencies.

precedents.cited_proposition: similar view to Imperial Tobacco that exchange profits on business-related foreign currency are taxable revenue receipts

precedents.citation: McKinlay H. M. Inspector of Taxes v. H. T. Jenkins Son 2 Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: McKinlay  H. M. Inspector of Taxes  v. H. T. Jenkins Son 2  Ltd. in which it was held that the profit by exchange operations would be capital profit if the profit did number companye in by way of business but by means of an investment in foreign currencies.

precedents.case_name: McKinlay (H.M. Inspector of Taxes) v. H.T. Jenkins & Son Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: profit from exchange operations is capital profit if it does not come in by way of business but by means of an investment in foreign currencies
precedents.cited_holding: the profit by exchange operations would be capital profit if the profit did number companye in by way of business but by means of an investment in foreign currencies
